comment: I use this to turn old tablets and smartphones into small remote monitors for our alarm systems and other things. Works great, and very useful!

title: Awesome
comment: I think that this idea is one of the greatest ever! It also takes up a very small amount of storage!

title: Useless
comment: Can't even run XTerm - hangs at any attempt and has to be killed. Completely useless.

title: Doesn't work very well
comment: Wasn't able to launch any programs except xclock, from my debian server.  Worst off all.. No info what's so ever how to use it or anything.  Completely creasy to spend time on something and then not to include at least a small how to or a few examples. 😕 got some info from comments, but hey it should have been available in the first place.

title: Not grest for full blown X Apps.
comment: Works ok for simple demos and apps, doesn't work for some more complicated x apps (like yhe apps fault as well).  Well done, though.

title: Great idea in principle. .
comment: but I've not actually got it to work with any consistency so far.

title: Didn't work at all for my fedora 20 host
It really works!
comment: (It doesn't work well, though...)

title: I appreciate the effort, but . . .
comment: I'm sort of baffled by all the praise.  No apps I use display properly (maybe because I'm using a tablet, not a phone?) Gedit initially displays alright, but then menus and their respective text begin to disappear.  I tried launching Nicotine (GTK-based SoulSeek client) and it was not centered on the screen and, like with Gedit, text was missing from many menus.  I'm using CM9 on an HP Touchpad; the server is running Debian Squeeze over a 801.11n connection. It is very alpha at this stage.

title: Does what I need it to do...
comment: Works perfectly to provide me remote x terminals.

title: Great achievement
comment: Even if it's slow and not all the keys on the keyboard work and the mouse doesn't click,  the author deserves kudos. In most cases this is what it takes to connect: xprogram --display x.x.x.x:0.0
Now Android is complete!

title: Okay, but has bugs
comment: It's okay. It sort of works. The one complaint I have is that it doesn't use RANDR extension, which it reminds me every time I start something like GIMP or GPicView.
Some simple instructions on how to tell applications to connect to it or configure connectbot would be worth the extra stars, right now its just a waste of space

title: Great
comment: It's a bit slow and buggy, but anyway - It works! Keep it up!
Massively useful!

title: Issue in running GUI based jar application
comment: Hey , I have launch and tested xclock, xeyes and xterm GUI in the X-Server from my application , but not able to run a jar file having single button component, even not able to run other linux based GUI executables . please help me out as soon as possible, give the information about it. Is there any alternate way to run it???

title: Works, sort of
comment: Can forward X apps (Firefox works, for instance) but have been unsuccessful in forwarding any window managers. Very cool, regardless.
choy

title: Works
comment: For those with port issues: x runs on 6000 by default. Port forwarding from an SSH session should use 6000 and use the command ‘export DISPLAY=localhost:0‘ as 0 is the starting point for x displays @ port 6000. Export display is not to the said port number but to the x display number where 0 is port 6000.  Missing some render capabilities forces windows managers to fail, but seems like a good starting point for x on android!

title: Miserable product
comment: Junk even to the best. He provides no info on how to do anything besides installing it on android. There are no samples to show how to get any desktop manager running remotely.

title: Some bugs on nexus 10
comment: I can only assume that this is a very good app. However, the volume rocker does not work as it should on my nexus 10. This may be my fault though.

title: Hope
comment: Can't tell if this is good or not until you can connect to a localhost and change the port.

title: Brilliant
comment: Thanks for this X server. Gives lots of extra options for local and remote X apps.

title: This is the best APP i have seen!
comment: This is one of the test. Good job dev! Use it everyday!

title: Developer should make a donate version of this!
comment: I'd happily pay $5 towards more development of this. I'm interested in use of Android as second monitor / display from a GNU/Linux laptop.

title: very clever stuff
comment: I too chroot into an arm linux environment; I fire up an xterm with "xterm -ls -C /bin/bash".  Impressive work for just one person! Thanks, Paul -- HTC Doubleshot, Cyanogenmod 9.0x-beta.

title: Nifty, but...
comment: ...no keyboard or mouse events. I can see Yahoo's homepage in Firefox though!

title: Very good idea !
comment: Can works on x86 and arm devices for Linux Installer. But some X features are not supported and it is crash...

title: Not too useful so far
comment: I chrooted into a local debian and tried running some applications, xeyes and xterm worked, the blackbox window manager also came up. DosBox started, but keyboard input was garbled for some reason. But that's about it, not even links2 worked in graphical mode, so you can forget about using firefox or other common applications. I know the x11 protocol is a mess, so I wasn't expecting much more than what I got. Good work nonetheless!

title: Conflicting with Lapdock/Webtop on Motorola phones
comment: X server conflicts with Motorola s Lapdock even when it is not started. (Since the path to X server precedes the path to Lapdock s own x server, X server is launched first on the HDMI connection.)

title: great start
comment: glad to see that x has been ported to android. works great with connectbot. sure there are a few bugs but that's to be expected in a epic port like this cant wait to see this mature.

title: great addtion to the Android family.
comment: great app, look forward to extending it with more front-end functionality.  thanks for all the work.

title: Wonderful, unbelievably wonderful!
comment: Seriously, developers are never seizing to amaze me on android. Its fantastic the things I see these days being built for the android os. This is fantastic, the first of its kind, and probably soon, the foundation of a whole new desktop windows environment for the android device. Really great.   Thank you dev. you are inspiring. :)   Hope to see an update sometime, and I hope some developers use this someday. Like someone mentioned it would be amazing if Terminal IDE implemented this.

title: Great Starting Point
comment: Excellent work and thanks for your effort! This app would be 5 stars if more bugs and ssh client other than ConnectBot, like VX ConnectBot, has been supported.

title: Nice Work
comment: We're. Happy To See This Released Nice Work Keep Doing What You Do, You Are Appreciated

title: doubtless 5
comment: this makes a device full computer.

title: Nicely done!
comment: I'd just like to see some integration with TerminalIDE - that'd be really useful.

title: This should have been built in
comment: This is a fantastic start. Needs to have a myriad of bugs fixed before it can be used to run a native os, but works okay for ssh streaming one program at a time. I plan to report any glitches I can pinpoint, and hope everyone else will do the same. We'll un-cripple Android yet!

title: Bc hdfgck
comment: Viketc begin

title: Keep it up!
comment: Efforts like this: 5 stars!

title: Great start
comment: Great start! That's my fives for!

title: Many thanks
comment: Just what a system admin would love to have in android in conjunction with  connectbot

title: Excellent!
comment: I am impressed! A real working X server on Android. Fired it up, used ConnectBot to ssh into my OpenBSD box, forwarded remote 6009 to localhost:6000, typed "twm -display localhost:9 & xterm -display localhost:9 & " in the prompt. Behold. A tad buggy, but really excellent. Keep it up!

title: Great start!
comment: If you've installed Debian in a chroot, you can start apps from a terminal by setting the display variable to 127.0.0.1:0. It actually works! (somewhat)... great job!  Needs a bit of work though, the SHAPE extension is used by some window managers like fluxbox. Keep it up!

title: Input problems
comment: Click events didn't work.  Most keyboard events didn't work.

title: excellent
comment: nice!

title: Pretty Good
comment: I like this app quite a bit. I think it would be awesome if, later down the road, we could get 3D support with actual hardware acceleration. I'm trying to find a way to play some games on my device with real hardware acceleration and have yet to find a way.

title: Great work
comment: Now someone needs to port gnome...
really a great app

title: Great start!
comment: It's great that someone has finally taken the time to write an X server for Android. I'd love to see different screen resolutions and pinching as a feature (mostly because phone screens are too small). From my limited trials, I could get basic things to work, but had a problem because RandR was required to run most window managers etc. I don't know how to disable RandR so maybe someone out there could write a small tutorial on how to get this working with ubuntu on android? Keep up the great work!

title: Already improving! Keep up the good work, dev!
comment: This server still has issues (I still use Xvnc + android-vnc-viewer for my X needs), but the developer has already fixed enough issues for several WMs and the Geany IDE to run under it without crashing it. My earlier comments about the mouse not working were in error; mouse clicking is done with volume rocker, and works fine. When I can run more programs at once without a crash, and change the mouse/keyboard shortcuts, I will have no further need for Xvnc.

title: Cool app
comment: Really appreciate the effort spent thus far; hope it would work better in the later revisions.
needed app

title: Very nice first shot
comment: On XOOM this app makes perfect sense.  If it was fulyly functional, I'd scratch my laptop when travelling - but I need to code. Could use with alternate way of mouse clicks -e.g., on screen or via menu. Also embeeded Wm would be cool, and start-up xterm to start SSH -X. Keep up the good work.

title: Good effort; needs progress
comment: Incomplete X implementation, missing most extensions, so not much use in current state  Xclock, xev launch, forget gnome or kde apps. Libreoffice calc looked like it was about to work. Started xaos, but couldnt click with the pointer...
Great product, glad to have a small standalone X server.

title: Exciting, but not ready for prime time
comment: Kudos! 4 stars for the accomplishment, but only 2 star for current useability. Sideloaded this on my Logitech Revue with Google TV.  Was able to serve X to PC-based LAN clients, but only basic ones (the pictured xterm, xeyes, etc). Of the WMs I tried, only TWM worked. No mouse right-click available. ^C didn't seem to work, or worked inconsistently. Looking forward to expanded X feature support. Also XAUTH and startup scripts (e.g. ssh launch apps).  Please also allow GoogleTV as a supported device so it needn't be sideloaded.  Thanks!

title: A good start.
comment: Works very well with a local debian chroot!  Hope you implement the SHAPE extension soon so we can use Fluxbox or Awesome WM or DWM :)

title: Thank you so much!
comment: I'm already smiling... when it's usable as an overlay I'll be truly happy :)

title: Well done
comment: I saw you post this on that forum. I'm the one that was docking with xvfb single window shares. I'm gonna play with this and see what magic I can brew.

title: Finally!
comment: Very cool.  Android devices do not ship with track pads anymore though, so it is impossible to interact besides waving the pointer. Suggest mapping volume buttons to mouse instead.

title: Doesn't do much
comment: At this point the functionality is very limited but it's a great achievement nonetheless. I've been playing with it most of the afternoon.

title: Great Start
comment: First of all, let me say kudos! to you, developer.  Android needs this bad.  There are a lot of geeks running chroots and having to suffer through vnc to see their x apps on their devices.  That having been said, it definitely needs work.  Most apps crash and it just isn't quite useable in its present state.  So please don't drop the ball. You're probably very busy but this is a real gem here and hopefully with just a little more hard work it will be perfect!

title: Nice
comment: Only thing I could run was xlogo (sun fire 240 Solaris 10) everything else caused the app to force close.

title: functional
comment: functional the little i tested opened a xterm and a xcalc im fetching a window manager to test more, lacks of options.. but seems very nice for a start
